<context_0>Article

## DNA Damage in Moderate and Severe COVID-19 Cases: Relation to Demographic, Clinical, and Laboratory Parameters

Kalashyan 1D , Naira Stepanyan (D) Hovhannisyan 1,2 @ Lily

- Laboratory of General and Molecular Genetics , Research Institute of Yerevan State University, Alex Manoogian 1, Yerevan 0025, Armenia; tigranharutyunyan@ysu.am (TH); angela.sargsyan@ysu.am (A.S.); lilikalashyan@ysuam (LK.); genetik@ysu.am (RA.); galinahovhannisyan@ysu.am (G.H:) Biology
- Department of Genetics and Cytology; Yerevan State University, Alex Manoogian 1, Yerevan 0025 , Armenia
- National Center for Infectious Diseases , Arno Babajanyan 21, Yerevan 0064, Armenia; nsstepanyang@gmailcom
- Jena University Hospital, Institute of Human Genetics, Friedrich Schiller University, Am Klinikum 1, D-07747 Jena, Germany

Abstract: The of the SARS-CoV-2 virus to cause DNA damage in infected humans requires its study as a potential indicator of COVID-19 progression.</context_0>
<relevance_0>0.519148051738739</relevance_0>
<context_1>DNA damage was studied in leukocytes of 65 COVID-19 patients stratified by sex, age, and disease severity in relation to demographic, clinical, and laboratory parameters.</context_1>
<relevance_1>0.49428755044937134</relevance_1>

content: TextBlock(citations=None, text="Based on the relevant information found, this study examined DNA damage in the leukocytes (white blood cells) of 65 COVID-19 patients. The researchers looked at how the DNA damage related to factors like the patients' sex, age, and disease severity. The goal was to understand DNA damage as a potential indicator of COVID-19 progression. The study found relationships between the patients' DNA damage levels and various demographic, clinical, and laboratory parameters. Overall, this study provides insights into how SARS-CoV-2 infection can cause DNA damage in infected individuals and how that damage may relate to the course of COVID-19 disease.", type='text')

content.content: The user is asking about the main indicators and predictors of COVID-19 severity based on the information in this study. To answer this, I need to identify any key findings or data from the study that relate to factors associated with more severe COVID-19 cases.

content: ToolUseBlock(id='toolu_01Vz25njnz1To8NpZRiNFjSh', input={'user_query': 'indicators and predictors for COVID severity in this study'}, name='find_relevant_content', type='tool_use')

content.content:
<context_0>Analysis of Prognostic Values of Indicators of COVID-19 Severity

To assess the potential value of different biomarkers for discrimination between moderate and severe COVID-19 patients, we analyzed the area under the receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves (AUC) of % DNA in tail, age, BMI, CRP, creatinine, and INR, which were significantly increased in the severe group (Figure 4). In the total group of patients, ROC analysis showed that the best predictors of severity were age (AUC = 0.749)

and INR (AUC = 0.724). Creatinine, DNA damage, and CRP with corresponding AUCs of 0.679, 0.678, and 0.625, respectively; were also indicative of severity with various levels of predictive (Figure 4a). The cut-off values that predicted disease severity in DNA in tail for DNA damage, and 50.0 mg/L for CRP (Table 6) optimal power

Figure 4.</context_0>
<relevance_0>0.7301554679870605</relevance_0>
<context_1>The patients in the severe group were older (median age 72 years  with interquartile range IQR of 63.0-70.0) than the patients in the moderate group (median age 62 years, IQR 44.5-69.5) (p < 0.05).

The elevated body mass index (BMI) indicates obesity in both groups of patients according to the criteria for Asian and South Asian populations [24]. A significant difference between the BMI of the control group and COVID-19 patients was identified (p 0.05). The BMI in the severe group is higher than in the moderate group  without a significant difference between them (29.1 (25.3-31.6) versus 26.1 (22.5-29.5)).

At least one comorbidity was recorded in 84.61% of the patients.</context_1>
<relevance_1>0.6838989853858948</relevance_1>

content:
TextBlock(citations=None, text='Based on the information provided in the study, the main indicators and predictors of COVID-19 severity include:

1. Age - Older age was associated with more severe COVID-19 cases. The median age was 72 years in the severe group compared to 62 years in the moderate group.

2. INR (International Normalized Ratio) - Higher INR values were predictive of more severe COVID-19, with an AUC of 0.724 in the ROC analysis.

3. Creatinine levels - Elevated creatinine was also indicative of disease severity, with an AUC of 0.679.

4. DNA damage - Higher levels of DNA damage in leukocytes, as measured by % DNA in tail, were associated with more severe COVID-19 (AUC = 0.678).

5. CRP (C-Reactive Protein) - Increased CRP levels, with a cutoff of 50 mg/L, were predictive of severe COVID-19 cases.

Additionally, the study found that at least one comorbidity was present in 84.61% of the COVID-19 patients, though the specific comorbidities were not detailed.', type='text')

tool_calls.tool_result:
<context_0>Analysis of Prognostic Values of Indicators of COVID-19 Severity

To assess the potential value of different biomarkers for discrimination between moderate and severe COVID-19 patients, we analyzed the area under the receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves (AUC) of % DNA in tail, age, BMI, CRP, creatinine, and INR, which were significantly increased in the severe group (Figure 4). In the total group of patients, ROC analysis showed that the best predictors of severity were age (AUC = 0.749)

and INR (AUC = 0.724). Creatinine, DNA damage, and CRP with corresponding AUCs of 0.679, 0.678, and 0.625, respectively; were also indicative of severity with various levels of predictive (Figure 4a). The cut-off values that predicted disease severity in DNA in tail for DNA damage, and 50.0 mg/L for CRP (Table 6) optimal power

Figure 4.</context_0>
<relevance_0>0.7301554679870605</relevance_0>
<context_1>The patients in the severe group were older (median age 72 years  with interquartile range IQR of 63.0-70.0) than the patients in the moderate group (median age 62 years, IQR 44.5-69.5) (p < 0.05).

The elevated body mass index (BMI) indicates obesity in both groups of patients according to the criteria for Asian and South Asian populations [24]. A significant difference between the BMI of the control group and COVID-19 patients was identified (p 0.05). The BMI in the severe group is higher than in the moderate group  without a significant difference between them (29.1 (25.3-31.6) versus 26.1 (22.5-29.5)).

At least one comorbidity was recorded in 84.61% of the patients.</context_1>
<relevance_1>0.6838989853858948</relevance_1>

final_output_text:
Based on the information provided in the study, the main indicators and predictors of COVID-19 severity include:

1. Age - Older age was associated with more severe COVID-19 cases. The median age was 72 years in the severe group compared to 62 years in the moderate group.

2. INR (International Normalized Ratio) - Higher INR values were predictive of more severe COVID-19, with an AUC of 0.724 in the ROC analysis.

3. Creatinine levels - Elevated creatinine was also indicative of disease severity, with an AUC of 0.679.

4. DNA damage - Higher levels of DNA damage in leukocytes, as measured by % DNA in tail, were associated with more severe COVID-19 (AUC = 0.678).

5. CRP (C-Reactive Protein) - Increased CRP levels, with a cutoff of 50 mg/L, were predictive of severe COVID-19 cases.

Additionally, the study found that at least one comorbidity was present in 84.61% of the COVID-19 patients, though the specific comorbidities were not detailed.
